summary: This is a summary order from the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit affirming a district court's July 23, 2020 order to unseal litigation materials, including Ghislaine Maxwell's April 2016 deposition transcript. The court rejects Maxwell's appeal, finding no abuse of discretion in the unsealing decision.

connections.description: Both listed as parties (defendant-appellant and respondent) in the same appellate case regarding unsealing of Maxwell's deposition materials.
Boies represented the opposing party (plaintiff-appellee) in the appeal against Maxwell.
Mueller represented Maxwell as her attorney in this appeal.
Walz represented intervenor Julie Brown in the appeal.
Judge Preska issued the district court order unsealing Maxwell's deposition materials that Maxwell appealed.

events.title: Maxwell's Deposition
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell gave a deposition in April 2016, the transcript of which became a central subject of the sealing/unsealing litigation.

events.title: District Court Unsealing Order
events.description: Judge Loretta A. Preska ordered the unsealing of certain litigation materials, including Maxwell's April 2016 deposition transcript.

events.title: Second Circuit Affirms Unsealing
events.description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit affirmed the district court's July 23, 2020 order unsealing Maxwell's deposition materials.

keyFacts: The Second Circuit Court of Appeals affirmed the unsealing of Ghislaine Maxwell's April 2016 deposition transcript and related litigation materials.
The court rejected Maxwell's argument that her privacy interests outweighed the public's interest in access to the judicial documents.
The deposition materials were deemed judicial documents subject to a presumption of public access, though with a lower presumption than materials connected to dispositive motions.
The appeal was separate from Maxwell's criminal case (United States v. Maxwell, No. 20-3061-cr), and the motion to consolidate the appeals was denied.
Intervenors including journalist Julie Brown and Miami Herald Media Company successfully argued for unsealing the materials.
